pages.title: Handling Anti
pages.content: Handling Anti-Scraping Measures with JavaScript - Got Detected Got Detected Home Overview Concepts Guides Glossary Handling Anti-Scraping Measures with JavaScript Home / Concepts / Handling Anti-Scraping Measures with JavaScript Handling Anti-Scraping Measures with JavaScript Understanding Anti-Scraping Measures: A Deeper Dive Anti-scraping measures are designed to protect websites from automated scripts (bots) that attempt to access or scrape their data without permission. Think of it like a digital "Do Not Disturb" sign for your website's resources. When dealing with anti-scraping measures, it's essential to remember that humans are not perfect either. In simple terms, a captcha (short for "completely automated public Turing test to tell computers and humans apart") is a security measure designed to distinguish human behavior from automation. Practical Insights: The Evolution of Captcha Solving One key challenge in captcha solving is the increasing sophistication of modern captchas, which makes it harder for solvers to keep up. To overcome this, captcha solvers must use advanced machine learning algorithms to analyze user behavior and distinguish between humans and automated scripts. Proxies can be used to bypass rate limits, access blocked content, or hide IP addresses. Proxies are typically classified into two main categories: Forwarding Proxy : This type of proxy sits between the client and server, forwarding requests from the client to the server.
